title: Are there some not well-known philosophers with interesting ideas you know of? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes, many. Robert Kane is relatively obscure. Yet he seems to me one of the greatest of contemporary philosophers. He was born in 1938, and he is still alive though retired from academia. Kane is the foremost exponent of the incompatibilist/indeterminist view of free will. Just call it “in/in” for short. The idea is that (a) we should hope that the universe, and especially our own actions, are somewhat indeterminate. This need not involve a transcendental soul — simple randomness can be involved. But indeterminism would be good news because it is necessary to make sense out of our intuitions about moral responsibility, etc. Determinism is incompatible with those important intuitions. Also, the in/in view says (b) that indeterminism is also the fact, our a priori hope is satisfied. The in/in position was perhaps first maintained by ancient atomists and Epicureans, when they spoke of atoms “swerving” randomly. In modern times, it was set out by William James in a famous essay, “The Dilemma of Determinism.” It was also expounded by at least two other Big Names since James — Isaiah Berlin and Karl Popper. Robert Kane is not as eminent as any of those folks, but he has been competently carrying the baton for these ideas in recent years.

I’ve been reading philosophy for 30+ years as a hobby and as a graduate student. The one philosopher who is not very well-known but who has truly worthwhile ideas is Ayn Rand. If you are wanting to read her work, start with Anthem, then Philosophy: Who Needs It, then The Fountainhead, and then Atlas Shrugged. They will change your life.

I like the east Indian Philosopher Jiddu Krishnamurti. He helps a person to think for him/her self. Sometimes I found him self contradictory but, that too, can help you to think for yourself. Perhaps it was one of his teaching tools. A good book of his is “Freedom From The Known”. You might like to have a hardcopy but you can also read it on-line via this PDF. https://selfdefinition.org/krishnamurti/Jiddu_Krishnamurt_Freedom_from_the_Known.pdf
One that I like, who is probably not so well-known today, and is under-appreciated: Eric Hoffer, who wrote “The True Believer” (1951). He was more of a sociologist than philosopher, but close enough.

The closest that I can give to answering this question is about an author named Mark Nepo. He wrote a book titled “7000 ways to listen.” From this book, somewhat paraphrased; “Self-expression is the tuning fork on the path to the sacred.”
